(CASTELLANO) Hay películas que se cocinan a fuego lento y otras que, como esta, se sirven con un aire envenenado desde el primer bocado. El menú atrapa por esa mezcla de thriller, comedia negra y sátira social que se va destapando plato a plato, hasta dejar al espectador en una posición incómoda y, al mismo tiempo, fascinante.

El aire teatral con el que está concebida la puesta en escena funciona como un ingrediente clave. Todo transcurre con una coreografía calculada, como si estuviéramos en una representación donde cada gesto, cada silencio y cada mirada forman parte de una obra mayor. Esa sensación de estar frente a una función casi ritual le da un atractivo especial.

Ralph Fiennes se mueve en el papel de chef como un auténtico maestro de ceremonias, hipnótico y perturbador. Su control de la sala es absoluto, hasta el punto de que la tensión se mastica como uno de los platos servidos. Frente a él, Anya Taylor-Joy encarna a la única voz discordante en un banquete de imposturas, logrando una química magnética que se convierte en el verdadero motor de la historia.

La película juega con la sátira de la alta cocina y la obsesión por el lujo, pero sin dejar de lado el suspense y el malestar que genera ver cómo cada plato se convierte en un comentario social disfrazado de experiencia culinaria. Hay momentos ridículos, otros siniestros y alguno que bordea el absurdo, pero siempre con un tono calculadamente incómodo que encaja con lo que se quiere contar.

No será la reflexión social más profunda ni el thriller más afilado, pero como espectáculo funciona de principio a fin. Es un menú que no deja indiferente: grotesco, elegante y cruel a partes iguales. Una experiencia que, como toda buena cena, se disfruta más por el viaje que por el último bocado.

(ENGLISH) Some films simmer slowly, while others, like this one, serve their poison from the very first bite. The Menu hooks you with its blend of thriller, dark comedy, and social satire, unfolding course by course until the viewer is left both uncomfortable and fascinated.

The theatrical atmosphere in the staging is a key ingredient. Everything moves with choreographed precision, as if we were watching a performance where each gesture, silence, and look is part of a greater design. That sense of ritual makes it even more engaging.

Ralph Fiennes inhabits the role of the chef as a true master of ceremonies, hypnotic and disturbing. His command of the room is absolute, and the tension becomes as tangible as one of the dishes being served. Opposite him, Anya Taylor-Joy embodies the lone voice of defiance at this banquet of pretension, and the chemistry between them is magnetic, driving the story forward.

The film pokes fun at haute cuisine and the obsession with luxury, but it never loses its sharp edge of suspense and unease, turning each dish into a social commentary disguised as a culinary experience. There are moments of absurdity, sinister touches, and even laughable extremes, but all of it fits into a carefully orchestrated discomfort.

It may not be the deepest social critique or the sharpest thriller, but as a spectacle it works from start to finish. This is a menu that doesn’t leave you indifferent: grotesque, elegant, and cruel in equal measure. An experience that, like a great dinner, is savored more for the journey than for the final bite.
Delicious! Excellent commentary on the pretentious of supposed "upper class".

Another film containing insults about God and Jesus Christ. The main male character uses the phrase "Holy f...ing...", which is a strong profanity, already two minutes into the film (00:02:14). The main  female character uses the phrase "Jesus f...ing Christ" at 01:34:10. Why?! Couldn't these insults be replaced? The actors repeatedly use God's name in vain from the very beginning and throughout the film. Why do they decide to sell their souls for their careers?
What is wrong with film directors today? They use so many offensive and disrespectful words that some viewers might perceive as blasphemy and mockery. Why do they hate Christians so much? They never mock other religions.
I lose respect for directors and actors who choose to use such offensive scripts.
Just an obvious film. You know exactly what to expect from the trailer. Been done before but Fiennes makes it.
Really fun satisfying watching entitled rich people get their comeuppance from someone who got pushed way too far.
Great movie, very good watch. 86/100

The cast’s performances were good! Each delivered sharp, layered portrayals that perfectly matched the film’s darkly satirical tone. The story was gripping from start to finish, blending tension, mystery, and dark humor in a way that keeps you hooked. A clever and well-executed concept that serves up both thrills and social commentary, definitely a feast!
Delightful commentary on society. There was not a single dull moment!
Turkey and ham are fitting terms to describe The Menu. Fiennes was pretty much doing Voldemort. Laughable.

The focus of the film rests entirely on Anya Taylor-Joy. Her performance not only captures the viewer's attention but also establishes a rhythm and tension that permeate every scene. Every gesture, every nuance of her interpretation demonstrates an absolute mastery of cinematic language. For her ability to carry the film with authority and precision, I award her an outstanding rating.
The narrative is very similar to the series Squid Game, where the captors already had information about the people before they even entered the location where they would be held. The suspense builds gradually, showing the fear of each individual until all the restaurant’s guests realize the gravity of the situation.
The development of the culinary experience is presented in an omakase style, with the chef crafting his art directly in front of the clients; there is no rigid menu, only a real-time gastronomic performance. The lighting reinforces professionalism while accentuating the drama and tension, aided by chefs whose presence seems to go beyond that of ordinary cooks.
Chef Slowik’s white attire conveys depth, authority, and control, while the darker tones of the rest of the cast enhance the visual suspense. There is no room for joy or distraction.
The scene transitions and timing chosen by the editor are spectacular, amplifying every key moment of suspense.
The CGI is seamlessly integrated, requiring not much of the green screen; but both the exterior and interior shots feel entirely realistic. The image quality is impeccable: outstanding sharpness and clarity, precise color grading, perfectly balanced lighting and exposure, and resolution that conveys absolute realism.

Typical American movie. Weird and full of foul language. Is it impossible nowadays for people to chat normally amongst themselves without having to use the f word every 30 seconds? Has everyone been brought up in the gutter? And no surprises that obesity is rife in the USA with the size of that cheeseburger! Good acting but a rubbish film.
Brilliant film and casting
Well just another day in one of Gordon Ramsey's eating houses! He is so strict!
Fantastic movie. Although the ending was a bit predictable, the movie did a great job in portraying the insatiable satisfaction of the uppermost class.
Great movie good test

A very original movie in what could have been a well trodden trail. Fiennes was as outstanding as one would expect - a class act. 
It would have been a better denouement if the cheesburger had been composed of the potentially poisonous meat in the smokehouse !
I really enjoyed this. It is so nice to watch something so completely different from  the usual bland, predictable movies today.  Foodies Beware!!
I would not say it is boring, but it is not entertaining either. It is completely pointless.
This film is gucking awesome, and it's even better on the second watch, but the ending isn't particularly as pleasurable
